}} The 'phi X 174' (or 'Î¦X174') bacteriophage was the first DNA-based genome to
be sequenced. This work was completed by Fred Sanger and his team in
1977. In 1962, Walter Fiers and Robert Sinsheimer had already
demonstrated the physical, covalently closed circularity of phi X 174
DNA. Nobel prize winner Arthur Kornberg used phi X 174 as a model to
first prove that DNA synthesized in a test tube by purified enzymes could
produce all the features of a natural virus, ushering in the age of synthetic
biology National Library of Medicine Profiles in Science. The Arthur
Kornberg Papers. "Creating Life in the Test Tube," 1959-1970. [http://profiles.nlm.nih.gov/ps/retrieve/Narrative/WH/p-nid/209/p-
docs/true link] In 2003, it was reported by Craig Venter's
group that the genome of Î¦X174 was the first to be completely assembled in vitro
from synthesized oligonucleotides. The Î¦X174 virus particle has also
been successfully assembled in vitro. Recently, Ã¸X174 was used as a
model show how its highly overlapped genome can be fully decompressed and still
remain functional.
